environment
 Pronunciation: in-'vI-r&(n)-m&nt, -'vI(-&)r(n)-
 Function: noun
 1 : the circumstances, objects, or conditions by which one is surrounded
 2 a : the complex of physical, chemical, and biotic factors (as climate, soil, and living things) that act upon an organism or an ecological community and ultimately determine its form and survival b : the aggregate of social and cultural conditions that influence the life of an individual or community

There are many on here that think at no point in the pregnancy is the being in the women a human. If this is true then maybe pictures are important.

 
 We believe it is human. We just don't believe it is legally a PERSON.
 
 BTW, the 8-week old fetus pictured earlier looks almost the same as a fetal pig, indeed, any mammalian fetus.

Well, you can certainly pick the one where a baby has a chance of survival outside the womb (being 24 weeks, give or take).
 
 But that is a tricky question. You could say once the gametes are formed (cell_death style) at conception, at implantation into the womb or at birth.
 
 It is at birth that the life has become independent of its reliance of the mother.
 
 What are your thoughts, doG?

 Yes, we could pick some point prior to birth wherein the fetus acquires some right of it's own. In doing so it would have to be weighed against the rights of the mother. This raises the question of abridging a mother's right in order to bestow rights to the fetus.
 
 If rights are to be granted to fetuses then it would seem fair that parents should have certain rights as well. At no time is a new child more dependant on it's mother than before birth and yet, she nor the father can claim the child as a dependant before it is born. 
 
 OTOH, if a mother has any right to have an unborn terminated by a third party then all laws that treat the killing of a pregnant woman as a double murder should be declared unconstitutional. Murder by definition is the killing of one human by another. If the fetus is treated as less than a human by any law then it should be treated as less than a human by all laws.
 
 I do not think reliance on the mother is necessarily a fair basis by which the rights of a developing child should be determined. Could it be said that the unborn has any choice but to be dependant? Should that be held against the unborn? 
 
 Should we continue to deny the father any rights until birth just because the father cannot bear the child? Except for cases of rape it seems that any child that is the result of consentual sex between two people should convey to each an equal right on determining that fate of the conceived. If a father wants a termination and the mother chooses to give birth it is that consentual act that obligates him to support the child. Shouldn't that also convey a right to vote to keep a child that the mother wants to abort? 
 
 I personally believe that mankind should acknowledge it's own scientific advances at some point and change that point in time that we define as the beginning of life. In older times it was reasonable to set that point at birth because man did not have the knowledge or technology to keep the baby alive outside of the womb. As time moves on that ability continues to move up the timeline towards conception. Maybe it is 24 weeks now but perhaps the day will come when science becomes so advanced as to be able to grow an infant entirely without a mother's womb. When do we decide that our knowledge and abilities make it unreasonable to treat birth as the beginning of life?

We believe it is human. We just don't believe it is legally a PERSON.
 
 BTW, the 8-week old fetus pictured earlier looks almost the same as a fetal pig, indeed, any mammalian fetus.

 
 Under most legal definitions a fetus actually would qualify for being a natural person. Although some definitions say "living, breathing" while others just say "living". 
 
 Nevertheless, I don't think it matters who is legally a person or not. A person is a person no matter if the law says so or not. Just like a black human was always a person even if the state didn't believe so. If we take the basic definition of a person...then any human qualifies.

Just seems a fairly backward way of looking at things, as the definition for person never thought of a case like abortion and when they did, (like the rules for causing miscarriage in the bible) they are very different from murder laws.
 
 Makes more sense to me to realise that definitions are fluid things in langauge and work out what makes the thing special enough to consider as being able to be put in the same category we include other 'people' (I do hate definition arguments though)
 
 As a far out hypothectical issue, judging personship purely on whether they are an alive human is going to cause problems should we ever meet aliens, build an AI or become post-human. However recognising the it is a certain level/development of mind that matters includes these possiblilities.

In fact, jitobear just stated that if there can be a way that the fetus can be permentantly attached the mother for life and the mother wants it, that this should be allowed and abortion should remain on the table for that length of time. Do you agree with this stance?

 
 Actually, Jitobear thought the question was stupid and was mostly answering to mock it.
 
 As a rule I hate dragging in the fantasy world of "what ifs" into this debate. People are not physically dependent on others organs past birth, your question was just another way to minimize and detract from the very real, very serious issue of pregnancy and what a woman faces during it.
 
 Quit trying to trivialize her issues as a means to stop abortion. Address them instead and you might actually succeed in bringing abortion down.

I have reviewed the posts of many of the pro-life proponents as well as the pro-choice proponents. If you remove the hateful, sarcastic, arrogant, holier-than-thou and more-educated-than-thou insulting rhetoric (which I am embarrassed to acknowledge I have participated in at times), this is what I get.
 
 Pro-lifers believe that it is right to force a woman to carry a fertilized ovum to term and give it birth.
 
 Pro-choicers believe that it is right to leave the woman the option to end the existence of the fertilized ovum gestating in her womb.
 
 I am curious of either side sees my statements as accurate.

Seems to be pretty much what the beleifs are about, though in both cases it is more complicated than that - pro-life ranges from abortion under no circumstance up to allowed in cases of rape or if there are medical problems. Likewise pro-choice goes from abortion should be an option at any time regardless of circumstance, down to abortion before a certain time should be an option with both views have a fairly large mix of different ones in between.

Yes, we could pick some point prior to birth wherein the fetus acquires some right of it's own. In doing so it would have to be weighed against the rights of the mother. This raises the question of abridging a mother's right in order to bestow rights to the fetus.
 
 If rights are to be granted to fetuses then it would seem fair that parents should have certain rights as well. At no time is a new child more dependant on it's mother than before birth and yet, she nor the father can claim the child as a dependant before it is born. 
 
 OTOH, if a mother has any right to have an unborn terminated by a third party then all laws that treat the killing of a pregnant woman as a double murder should be declared unconstitutional. Murder by definition is the killing of one human by another. If the fetus is treated as less than a human by any law then it should be treated as less than a human by all laws.

 
 With regard to murder remember it is a legal term- murder/first degree homicide is the premeditated unlawful killing of a human being by another. There are instances where it is lawful for one person to take the life of another. You need to be wary in how you apply such a term in this debate. In general the law and foetuses varies from country to country- in the UK the foetus legally becomes a person at the 24th week of gestation.
 
 
I do not think reliance on the mother is necessarily a fair basis by which the rights of a developing child should be determined. Could it be said that the unborn has any choice but to be dependant? Should that be held against the unborn?

 
 No the unborn has zero choice in this matter. But it is a bit of an oxymoron to refer to the choice of the unborn as it can only ever have what legal protections/privilages are bestowed by others on its behalf, until such a time as it becomes recognised as a person in law.
 
 With regard to the latter part of this statement we have two conflicting interests to consider here- the desire of a person(s) to be free of an unwanted pregnancy for whatever reason and the obligation of the state to protect the lives of its citizens. With such disparate matters there are no straight forward answers that do not completely ignore one set of needs so a compromise has to be found.
 
 
Should we continue to deny the father any rights until birth just because the father cannot bear the child? quote Except for cases of rape it seems that any child that is the result of consentual sex between two people should convey to each an equal right on determining that fate of the conceived. If a father wants a termination and the mother chooses to give birth it is that consentual act that obligates him to support the child. Shouldn't that also convey a right to vote to keep a child that the mother wants to abort?

 
 Sadly no, the law will only deal with the wishes of the mother as she bears 100% of the biological burden of pregnancy. Men would do well to bear this in mind when engaging in sex- is that woman 100% committed to bearing my child?
 
 
I personally believe that mankind should acknowledge it's own scientific advances at some point and change that point in time that we define as the beginning of life. In older times it was reasonable to set that point at birth because man did not have the knowledge or technology to keep the baby alive outside of the womb. As time moves on that ability continues to move up the timeline towards conception. Maybe it is 24 weeks now but perhaps the day will come when science becomes so advanced as to be able to grow an infant entirely without a mother's womb. When do we decide that our knowledge and abilities make it unreasonable to treat birth as the beginning of life?

 
 Well, the 24 weeks I quoted you is a figure based on the best available medical technology- without advanced care such a premature birth would result in the death of the baby anyway (IIRC as it stands 24 weeks premature has around a 10% survival chance, with care).
 
 A law based on such medical opinion has to be sensitive to advances in the care of premature babies and be adjusted if necessary.

I have reviewed the posts of many of the pro-life proponents as well as the pro-choice proponents. If you remove the hateful, sarcastic, arrogant, holier-than-thou and more-educated-than-thou insulting rhetoric (which I am embarrassed to acknowledge I have participated in at times), this is what I get.
 
 Pro-lifers believe that it is right to force a woman to carry a fertilized ovum to term and give it birth.
 
 Pro-choicers believe that it is right to leave the woman the option to end the existence of the fertilized ovum gestating in her womb.
 
 I am curious of either side sees my statements as accurate.

 
 If I were to play devils advocate I'd say your statements are somewhat biased against the pro-lifers.
 
 A more impartial summary might read thus:
 
 Pro-lifers believe that the unborn have to be afforded the same legal protection as a "born person" (for want of a better term) even if this means forcing a woman to bear an unwanted pregnancy to birth. At such time they (read the State) will take full responsibility of any child that was unwanted by its mother and care for its needs.

OC:
 
 For a statement to be balanced, I try to use the same sterile terminology in describing the position of each. I chose not to adopt their particular buzz words (such as "unborn" or "reproductive rights", etc.)

OC:
 
 For a statement to be balanced, I try to use the same sterile terminology in describing the position of each. I chose not to adopt their particular buzz words (such as "unborn" or "reproductive rights", etc.)

 
 I wasn't refering to your use of terminology, but the inherent meaning such words carry, hence why I cited the impartiality. As much as I disagree with the ardent pro-life viewpoint, to say that forcing women to bear unwanted pregnancies is their only interest in this debate is not entirely representative, so I tried to put it in context.
 
 You did ask what we all thought......... ;)

OC:
 
 So your take was my statement with regard to the pro-life position was not impartial -- can I assume that you think that in comparison my statement about the pro-choice position was impartial?

Pro-lifers believe that it is right to force a woman to carry a fertilized ovum to term and give it birth.
 

 
 The problem with that definition, though, is that saying the woman is forced tends to present the image of the woman having something forced onto her that she did not cause and is not responsible for. With the exception of rape, this is not the case.

The problem with that definition, though, is that saying the woman is forced tends to present the image of the woman having something forced onto her that she did not cause and is not responsible for. With the exception of rape, this is not the case.
No, the definition says that her options are taken away; her free will is taken from her. I guess you can say that is similar to rape, but not even rape forces a woman into a 9 month gestation period, she can get an abortion.

I have reviewed the posts of many of the pro-life proponents as well as the pro-choice proponents. If you remove the hateful, sarcastic, arrogant, holier-than-thou and more-educated-than-thou insulting rhetoric (which I am embarrassed to acknowledge I have participated in at times), this is what I get.
 
 Pro-lifers believe that it is right to force a woman to carry a fertilized ovum to term and give it birth.
 
 Pro-choicers believe that it is right to leave the woman the option to end the existence of the fertilized ovum gestating in her womb.
 
 I am curious of either side sees my statements as accurate.

 
 I won't speak for pro-choice but your pro-life arguement is still flawed. You are still hung up on just the women and fail to see a child is in the mix as well. Perhaps you could say "Pro-lifers believe that it is a right to force a woman to not kill the baby she is carrying"...even this uses "emotional" words like "force".
 
 Maybe you see no difference but there is one. Your post tended to degrade the baby more then would be accurate. I could say "pro-choicers believe that it is a right to end the life of a human being by a bigger bipedal primate mammal" Not really an unbiased way to look at it now is it?

Steeeeve:
 
 I guess what I was trying to do was state the pro-life position from a pro-choice viewpoint and the pro-choice position from a pro-life viewpoint. I didn't realize that until I read your post, so thanks.
 
 To a pro-lifer, basically, abortion "ends the existence" of the fetus. I did not want to use the inflammatory "m" word, but I think I am correct in stating that that is the bottom line of the pro-life position.
 
 To a pro-choicer, basically, government laws ending or abridging access to abortion eliminates a woman's free will and insists on a 9 month gestation period and a birthing process.

OC:
 
 So your take was my statement with regard to the pro-life position was not impartial -- can I assume that you think that in comparison my statement about the pro-choice position was impartial?

 
 Yes, I should have noted that in my first response. I suppose you might add foetus along with ovum.
 
 I think its interesting to try summarise such a complex debate into succinct statements- I wonder what others (Steeeve aside as he has already commented, at least on Pro-life) will have to say on the idea?

Steeeeve:
 
 I guess what I was trying to do was state the pro-life position from a pro-choice viewpoint and the pro-choice position from a pro-life viewpoint. I didn't realize that until I read your post, so thanks.

 Not sure why we would use "existence"...I guess life would be the better term.

 Probably a useless effort to avoid the screaming and yelling that this subject creates, but...

The human body is composed of a myriad of different "organisms": complex structures of interdependent and subordinate elements whose relations and properties are largely determined by their function in the whole. If we start to claim they are all "human life" where the heck will we be?

Tastyfish also stated that the human zygote is a "parasite," and it seems to me that humans have a right to rid themselves of "parasites" if they don't choose to lend them sustenance, often at a cost to themselves.

 They are all part of the same organism even though are all alive, however a zygote is a part of a different organism and is also alive. It would be like saying Rastafarians or Jehovah's Witnesses couldn't get rid of a tapeworm to class it as part of the mother.
